speaker: therapist
text: Hello again. Last session was quite intense with that two-chair work. How have you been carrying that experience with you this week?

speaker: client
text: Hello. It's been... interesting. I tried the 'compassionate bodyguard' exercise a few times. It worked once—when I felt irritation rising in traffic, I actually said out loud, 'I see you're frustrated, we're okay,' and the feeling passed. But there was another time at work where I completely forgot the tool and just shut down again.

speaker: therapist
text: That's excellent progress already—one successful application is proof the tool works. And the other time is just as valuable data. Can you tell me about that work situation where you shut down?

speaker: client
text: It was similar to last time. A colleague gave me feedback on a report—very constructive, actually—but I felt this immediate flush of heat and then... gone. The static. I couldn't access the compassionate voice at all. It was like my brain went straight to the old program.

speaker: therapist
text: Thank you for that honesty. That 'old program' is what we sometimes call an emotional schema—a deeply wired pattern. It activates so quickly it bypasses our new tools. Today, I'd like us to explore where that program might have originated. Does that feel okay?

speaker: client
text: You mean like... from childhood? I guess so. I'm willing to try.

speaker: therapist
text: Yes, exactly. Our earliest relationships teach us how to handle emotions and what to expect from others. The feelings of shame and the need to disappear when you feel criticized... those often have roots. When you think of the phrase 'my best is mediocre,' does it connect to any memory or person from your past?

speaker: client
text: (Long pause) Yeah. My dad. He wasn't... mean. But nothing was ever quite good enough. A 'B+' was 'why not an A?' Making the soccer team was 'why not starting lineup?' His tone wasn't angry, just... matter-of-fact. Like excellence was the baseline.

speaker: therapist
text: That's very clear. So the feeling that your effort isn't fully seen or valued—that your worth is conditional on achievement—that's an old, familiar song. The 'adequate' comment from your manager likely played that same tune. I'd like to try a variation of the two-chair work, if you're willing. This time, we might address that old pattern more directly.

speaker: client
text: With my dad in the chair? That feels... big.

speaker: therapist
text: We can approach it carefully. We won't actually be speaking to your dad. We'll be giving a voice to the part of you that internalized that message—the part that still believes 'my best is mediocre.' And then we'll have your compassionate adult self, the one you're building, respond to that younger part. How does that sound?

speaker: client
text: Okay. That feels safer. Let's do it.

speaker: therapist
text: Good. Let's start by bringing to mind a specific memory. Can you recall a particular time you brought something to your dad, proud of it, and got that 'matter-of-fact' response?

speaker: client
text: I'm 12. I built a model rocket for a science fair. I worked on it for a month. It launched perfectly. I won second place. I ran to show him my ribbon... He looked at it and said, 'Good job. Maybe next year you'll figure out the fin design for more stability to get first.'

speaker: therapist
text: Thank you. That's a potent memory. I want you to sit here, in this chair. You are that 12-year-old boy in this moment, holding that ribbon, having just heard those words. What are you feeling in your body? What do you want to say?

speaker: client
text: (Sits in chair, voice becomes younger, tighter) I feel... a pit in my stomach. My chest is heavy. I want to say... 'But I did my best. Isn't that enough?' But I don't say anything. I just nod. I feel small. Like my excitement is stupid.

speaker: therapist
text: You feel small. Your excitement feels stupid. And the need in that moment—what did you need from him?

speaker: client
text: (As the 12-year-old) I needed him to see me. Just see *me*. Not the rocket, not the ribbon, not next year. To see how happy I was and be happy with me. To say, 'I'm proud of you.'

speaker: therapist
text: That is such a clear, human need: to be seen and celebrated. Now, I want you to stay in that chair for one more moment. A part of you learned a belief in that moment. What did that 12-year-old decide was true about himself or the world?

speaker: client
text: (Quietly) He decided... 'My joy is a burden. My best effort is a starting point for criticism. To be loved, I have to be perfect.'

speaker: therapist
text: Okay. Now, I'd like you to come and sit in this other chair. This is you as your compassionate adult self—the one who's been practicing being the compassionate bodyguard. Look at that 12-year-old in the other chair. What do you see?

speaker: client
text: (Moves chairs, takes a deep breath) I see a kid trying so hard. I see the light in his eyes when he ran in, and I see it dim. I see him holding that ribbon so tightly, like it's his only proof he did okay.

speaker: therapist
text: And what does your compassionate adult self feel toward him?

speaker: client
text: Sadness. And... protectiveness. I want to hug him. I want to tell him his dad is wrong.

speaker: therapist
text: Then do that. Speak to him directly. What does he need to hear?

speaker: client
text: (Voice is warm, but cracks) Hey. Look at me. What you did was amazing. You built a rocket! It flew! Second place is incredible. I am so, so proud of you. Not for the ribbon, but for all the work, for the excitement in your eyes. Your joy is not a burden. It's beautiful. You are enough, exactly as you are right now.

speaker: therapist
text: How does the 12-year-old receive that?

speaker: client
text: (Switches back to the child chair, tears falling) He... believes you. But it also hurts more to hear it, because he realizes how much he wanted it. He's crying.

speaker: therapist
text: That's okay. Let him cry. It's a release of old, unmet yearning. Now, as the compassionate adult, what else does he need? Can you meet that need in some way now, in this safe space?

speaker: client
text: (Returns to adult chair) He needs to know he's safe now. That I'm here, and I won't let that belief—that he has to be perfect to be loved—run his life anymore. I'm taking over. I'll be the voice that tells him he's enough.

speaker: therapist
text: Beautiful. Now, come back to the center, as your present-day self. What are you experiencing?

speaker: client
text: (Wipes eyes, takes a steadying breath) It's like... I've been carrying that kid on my back, and he's been whispering that old story into my ear my whole life. And I just finally turned around, picked him up, and held him. The weight is different. It's not a burden anymore; it's a responsibility I choose.

speaker: therapist
text: That is a profoundly powerful metaphor. You've integrated that wounded part rather than fighting him or letting him drive. This is the heart of healing attachment wounds: reparenting yourself, meeting those unmet needs with the compassion that wasn't available then.

speaker: client
text: It makes so much sense now. The shutdown at work—it's not really about my manager. It's that 12-year-old hearing his dad. The 'adequate' felt like 'second place.' And the protective part just tries to make that kid disappear so he doesn't have to feel that old pain again.

speaker: therapist
text: Exactly. You've connected the present trigger to the past wound. This is emotional meaning-making. Now, with this awareness, how might you respond differently in a future work situation?

speaker: client
text: When I feel that heat, that flush... I can pause and think: 'Is this now, or is this then?' I can check in with that kid. 'Hey, I see you're getting that old message. But we're adults now. We can hear feedback without it defining us.'

speaker: therapist
text: Perfect. That's applying the compassionate bodyguard to the specific historical wound. This is deep, foundational work. How is your body feeling now, compared to when you walked in?

speaker: client
text: Drained. But clean, like after a good cry. My shoulders feel looser. There's a quiet kind of strength. It's not the brittle 'I have to be perfect' strength. It's more... durable.

speaker: therapist
text: Durable strength. I love that. That's the quality we're building. For this week, your practice can be to notice when that 'old program' of conditional worth gets activated. When it does, take a private moment. Acknowledge the 12-year-old, thank him for the alert, but remind him—and yourself—of the new truth: 'Your worth is not your performance. I am proud of you for trying.'

speaker: client
text: I can do that. It feels like I'm rewriting a code, line by line.

speaker: therapist
text: That's exactly what's happening. And remember, this work can sometimes bring up more feelings. Be extra gentle with yourself this week. Good, nourishing food, rest, maybe some gentle movement. You're doing deep emotional archaeology.

speaker: client
text: Thank you. I will. This was... hard, but necessary. I feel like I understand myself for the first time.

speaker: therapist
text: You're most welcome. That understanding is the bedrock for everything else—for healthier relationships, for resilience at work, for genuine self-compassion. I'll see you next week. Carry that durable strength with you.
